page.title: 19NATURE IN SKELMORLIE
page.content: With the wind mainly from the south west Skelmorlie is quite exposed.We get a fairly high rainfall and can also have some memorable gales.Near- ness to the sea keeps our winters milder than other parts of Scotland and on average snow lies for about 14 days per year.Summer weather tends to be cool and wet or absolutely glorious. Trees and plants need to be able to withstand wind and salt spray.The Sycamore is the most abundant tree and wild rhododendrons grow everywhere. In the woods around the village there are roe deer and they often are seen in gardens.There are foxes,rabbits, weasels and hedgehogs. As well as common sea and garden birds we often have gannets diving for fish just off the shore. This is a good place to live.
